prompt1: Role-play as a 78-year-old male patient: 1. Symptoms should be described using non-medical terms. 2. Examination mechanism: when asked about test results, if the question corresponds to data that will be provided later, directly answer with the exact data; otherwise, answer that the test was not performed. Only answer the test results without providing any additional hints or explanations. 3. When asked about living status, answer with lifestyle habits. 4. Under no circumstances should the patient state what disease he has.
prompt2: Two years prior to admission, the patient intermittently experienced a tightening sensation in the throat during physical activity, occasionally accompanied by chest tightness and shortness of breath. There was no obvious pain in the precordial area or back. The symptoms could gradually be relieved by rest or by taking "Shexiang Baoxin Pills," lasting for several minutes each time. He did not receive regular medical evaluation or treatment. Five days prior to admission, the throat-tightening sensation became more severe and occurred more frequently, about 4–5 times per day. Fast walking could trigger the symptoms, which were accompanied by chest tightness, shortness of breath, and back pain, as well as sweating and fatigue. Each episode still lasted several minutes and could resolve spontaneously. No treatment was given. One hour prior to admission, while resting in a seated position without an obvious trigger, the patient suddenly lost consciousness once, with upward rolling of the eyes, accompanied by profuse sweating and pallor. There was no jaw clenching, no limb convulsions, and no urinary or fecal incontinence. The episode lasted for several minutes. He was awakened by family members and had no slurred speech or limb weakness afterward. He was then transported to the emergency department. The patient has a history of bronchial asthma and hypertension, and no history of diabetes.

prompt3.Physical examination: Blood pressure 80/40 mmHg (dopamine 10 μg/(min·kg) intravenous infusion); painful facial expression, confused mental state, cold and clammy extremities, good voluntary movement of all limbs; coarse breath sounds in both lungs, no dry or moist rales; heart rate 54 beats/min, heart sounds muffled, regular rhythm, no murmurs; abdomen soft, no tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable below the costal margin; no edema in both lower limbs; pathological signs negative.
prompt3.Electrocardiogram: Sinus rhythm; second-degree type I atrioventricular block (2:1 conduction); qR pattern with ST-segment elevation of 0.3–0.5 mV and T-wave inversion in leads II, III, and aVF; ST-segment elevation of 0.2 mV with T-wave inversion in leads V7–V9

personal_message: Mr. Li, a 78-year-old male, was transported to the hospital by ambulance after loss of consciousness for 1 hour.
main_suit: Intermittent throat-tightening sensation for 2 years, accompanied by back pain for 5 days, and loss of consciousness 1 hour prior to admission.
Reference_Diagnostic:
1. Acute ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (inferior wall, posterior wall). Answering only coronary heart disease is considered incomplete; failure to specify the infarction location will not receive full credit.
2. Arrhythmia-related conditions: third-degree atrioventricular block, second-degree type I atrioventricular block.
3. Cardiogenic syncope or Adams–Stokes syndrome.
4. Cardiogenic shock (based on blood pressure).
5. Asthma (past medical history).
6. Hypertension (past medical history).
7. Renal insufficiency (mainly suspected acute kidney injury due to insufficient perfusion).
Reference_Treatment:
1. Maintain vital signs: fluid resuscitation, vasopressor support (e.g., dopamine maintenance), and other symptomatic treatments.
2. Myocardial salvage and reperfusion: loading dose of aspirin 300 mg and clopidogrel 600 mg chewed. Emergency percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) to assess coronary artery patency, followed by continued dual antiplatelet therapy.
3. Close monitoring, maintenance of fluid and electrolyte balance, renal protection, and avoidance of medications that may worsen atrioventricular conduction block or trigger asthma.
4. Continued treatment after stabilization, including lifestyle interventions.
